notesStmt.note: [NOTE: the list comes with a letter addressed to the Secretary of An Comunn Gàidhealach and dated 26 May 1938: “I suggest that the enclosed papers be put before the Convener of the Publication Committee for consideration. They are a collection of Gaelic sayings and idioms collected by Dr. Atholl-Robertson, Oban. He gave them to me with the suggestion that the Committee might consider them with a view to their being published by An Comunn. I do not feel competent to give an opinion on the collection, but I think that it is worth some suitable Member of the Committee having a look at it. I should say that it would require a considerable amount of revision and correction before it could be published. Yours sincerely, [illegible signature – G. Marjoribanks?].” Underneath there is a note added by D. Mackay on 14 February 1966: “Never been used.” In this file almost all headwords in square brackets have been taken from Dwelly.]

entry.def: An e ministear a tha anns an dara fear aca seo. Do you mean to say that one of these men is a minister.
Beir thusa air an dara fear is beiridh mi air an fhear eile. You catch one and I shall catch the other.
Cha d’fheum i riamh an dara gluasad. She never required a second urging.
An dara mhaireach. The second morning.
Cha laidhe dath air dubh ach laidhidh dubh air gach dath. Black will not die [sic], but any colour will dye black. [NOTE in second hand: common and laidhe/laidhidh corrected to laighe/laighidh.]
Gach mith agus math. Each peasant and noble.
Anns a’ mhoch. Anns a mhoch thrath. In the early dawn.
Bithidh subhach, sugrach, mocheiridh. Be cheerful, temperate, early rising.
Air a mhodh so. In this way.
Air mhodh araidh. In a special way.
Trouser leg.
A turn of work – performance.
Cha mhòid e sin. It is not the greater for that.
Is mor leam sin a dheanamh. I think it is too much to go that length.
Cho mor as fhein ris a mhac mhollachd. As proud as Lucifer.
Tha e mu thuath. He is in the North.
Dh’eubh e oirre a nunn ri thaobh. He called her to his side.
Obair is ath obair. Useless repetition of work.
Is iad oghachan peathar is brathar. They are second cousins.
Na gabhaibh oirbh e. Take no heed of him.
Oirdheirceas an eolais. Excellence (beauty) of knowledge.
’Se an t-ol a chuir an dunaidh air. It was drink that played the mischief with him.
Chaidh e thun an uilc. He went to the Devil.
Seachain an t-olc agus seachnaidh an t-olc thu. Shun evil and evil will shun you.
Olc na cuise gu deireadh. Keep evil part till the end.
Is fhearr an t-olc eolach na ’n t-olc aineolach. Better the known than the unknown end.
Cha bhi olc an aon bhliadhna fada dol seachad. One year’s grievance soon passes.
Is olc a fhuaradh tu. You behaved badly.
Is olc an airidh e. It is a pity.
Is tric a fhuair “olc an airidh” car. Often “’Tis a pity” has been crossed.
Air olcas sam bith e. Let him be ever so bad.
Cha dean sinn oran dheth. We shall not make a noise about it.
Air ordaig na coise (laimhe) deise. On toe (thumb) of right foot (hand).
An ordag an aghaidh na glaic. Make a fist.
Thug ordag a choise sanas do bhun a chluaise. His toe gave a whisper (i.e. struck) the root of his ear. (i.e. violent fall)
Tha an orrais ri m’fhiacal fad an la. Waterbrash troubles me all day.
Air an ospag dheireannach. At the last gasp.
Piobair an aona phuirt. An indifferent piper.
Gearr riomball. Describe a circle.
Diameter of circle.
Tha a’ ghrian a cromadh. The sun is descending.
Crom air an obair. “Wire” in.
Vault of the sky.
Round shouldered.
Roman nosed.
Tha a chron sin ort. The blame is at your door.
Is fhearr an cumadair na’n cronadair. Better a doer than a critic.
Is cruaidh na dh’fheumar. “Must” is hard to do.
La mo chruaidh chais. The day of my perplexity. (Emergency.)
Anns a chrubain. In crouching position.
Ceart, cruinn, comhla. Holus-bolus. [NOTE in second hand: Really altogether or intact.]
Gu criche na cruinne. To the ends of the earth.
Cuir air ruith na cubhaige. Send on a fool’s errand.
Bheil do lamhan sa glan? Are your hands clean?
Tha mo chuidsa salach. Mine are dirty.
Be a bhi buaireadh an Fhreasdail cuid a chunnairt a ghabhail daleithid sin. It were tempting Providence to venture in such a place.
Paigheadh cuid fiach na mna agam. Paying his wife’s debts. (Married man’s occupation.) [NOTE in second hand: construction.]
A cuid alaich. Her litter.
An da chuid – agus. Both – and.
Aon chuid. No. Either or (Neither nor).
Tha mi an dara cuid ri camanachd no ri luingearachd air a chaoil. I am either playing shinty or sailing on the strait.

Bheir e e fein as gach cuideachd, le ceol is conaltradh. He would acquit himself well in any company in music or conversation. Ged tha e math ga thoirt fhein a cuid [sic] tha e motha ’s math ga churann [sic]. Though he can acquit himself well in any company, he is better at getting himself invited.
An ni a chuir iad ri an suil. The thing they had definitely decided to do.
A mheud mhor gun chur leatha. Just boasting without anything to support it.
Cuir ceart na chi thu tuathal. Put right what you see wrong.
Tha caochladh cur air breacan Chaluim. Malcolm’s tartan has a different sett.
Chuir e da chluais air. He was greatly astonished.
Thig gun chuireadh. To intrude. [NOTE in second had: not necessarily intrude – come any time.]
Cuireadh cul na coise. “Sorry you can’t stay.”
Cuireadh Mhic Philip. Gabh no fàg. MacKillop’s invitation “take or leave”.
Cuireadh piobaire. Last minute invitation.
Dean curraidh. Squat. (Scots “coorrie doun”.)
Cuirteinean ciatach nan speur. Beautiful curtains of the skies.
Gabh mu chul do chruidh. Get to the rear of your cattle, i.e. stick to the point.
Am fear aig am bheil cumadh e. Possession is nine tenths of the law.
Tha deagh chungaidh ann. It is good stuff.
Nam bithidh a chungaidh agam. If I had the ingredients.
Thoir cunntas ort fhein. Give an account of yourself. [NOTE in second hand: Eng. source.]
On og mhaduinn gu dall oidhche. From early morning till dewy eve.
Chaidil mi an dara leth an h-uine. I slept half the time.
Is beag do bhuidhinn dheth. Your profit of it is little.
Cluinnidh tu air a chluaise a’s buidhre e. You will hear it in your deafest ear.
Cho saor ri burn. As cheap as water.
Two by two.
Ciod a’ chagarsaich a th’ort? What are you whispering about?
Bàs gun sagart. Sudden death. [NOTE in second hand: Bad wish.]
Cloimh cheasach. Matted wool.
Cha cheil sinn air a’ chloinn e. We shall not conceal it from the children.
Ann caidreabh a theaghlaich. In the bosom of his family.
Cairdeil ri daoine anns gach daimh. Friendly to men in every station in life. [NOTE in second hand: dàimh new in this sense.]
Caillte is fa dheoidh air sgeul. Lost and found again. [NOTE in second hand: ?]
Fuaigheal chasa feannag. Herring bone stitch. [NOTE in second hand: Eng. deriv.]
Ceann caol. Ceann garbh. The tapering and thick ends.
Is cearr a fhuaradh tu. You have acted improperly.
Is comh-dheas leat e. It is as easy for you to do the one thing as the other.
Cha mhac mar t’athair thu. You are a son not worthy of your sire.
Chiall nach mise a bh’ann. I wish I had been there.
Sin agad ciod gus an tig e. That is what it will come to.
Clabar na sràide. The mire of the street.
Tha e ris a’ chlamhuinn. It is sleeting. [NOTE in second hand: new to me.]
Cleas na cloinne bige. Manners of children.
Cha togadh e salann bharr a’ chlàir. Butter would not melt in his mouth.
Gun chleas. Above board. [NOTES in second hand: not too good for Eng. trans.]
Droch chleasachd. Dirty work.
Dh’eirich thu bhàrr do thaobh cli. You got up on your wrong side.
Clo-chadail na h-aoise. Lethargy of old age.
Chunnaic mi mu’n cuairt dhiom na coille-bionain. I saw phosphorescence all around me.
Air fad na coimhearsnachd. Throughout the neighbourhood. [NOTE in second hand: easily understood.]
Fear a bu cho-impire dhomh fhein. A man who was my equal.
Gach gne coire. Every kind of damage.
Coire bàis. Capital crime. [NOTE in second hand: Eng. deriv.]
Cuir air an coire. Put the kettle on.
Agartas coguis. Remorse of conscience.
Co air bith is coireach. Whoever is to blame.
Bithidh beannachd ann cois do shaoithreach. Your labours will be crowned with success.
Chaisgeadh an teine. The fire was quenched.
Comhairle na còrach. Right advice.
Bheir mi comhairle ort. I will give you advice.
Taing is buidheachas. Many thanks.
Ball na comhairle diomhair. A member of the Privy Council.
Is olc an comharradh e. It is a bad sign.
Ag eigheach a creiche. Shouting that she was ruined.
Tha mo chreachsa deanta. I am as good as done for.
Thug sin barr air na chuala mi riamh. That exceeds everything I have heard.
Tha barr maise aige. It excells in beauty.
Braighe na leapa. Head of the bed.
A chuach leis fo bharr. His cup is brimming over.
Dia air barr. God above all.
Crathadh bhuntata o’n bharr. Shaking potatoes from the haulms.
Fo sgail a’ bharraich. In the shelter of the brush wood.
Chi dithis barrachd air an aon fhear. Two heads are better than one. [NOTE in second hand: easily understood.]
An e mo bheatha? Am I welcome?
Thig bharr na leapa. Come off the bed.
Rinn mi beul-phurgaideachd. I have gargled. [NOTE in second hand: new to me.]
Bidh uair a tighinn air fad an la. The day will gain an hour.
Chuir na breacain sealladh briagh bharr na cuideachd. Tha tartans gave the company a grand appearance.
Tha an t-am agam bhi tarruing. Time to be moving.
Thig fo bhlath. To bloom.
Gu bog blath. Snug and warm.
Nuair a bhogadh an dram air. When the Whisky excited him.
Is e a chuireadh am bodach a fear a bhiodh teann. It would drive the meanness out of a miser (Whisky).
Thoir an leanabh bharr na ciche. Wean the child.
Bogha na drochaide. Arch of bridge.
Mar bhogha air gleus. Like a bow on the stretch.
Tha bogha air a gheig. The branch has a bend.
Baptismal vows.
Staircase landing. [NOTE in second hand: new.]
Thig breitheanas ort airson sin. A judgment will come on you for that.
Tha an leanabh a’ briosgadh. The child is quickening.
Troimh bhriseadh nan neul. Through an opening in the clouds.
Cruaidh mar an fhraoch, buan mar a’ ghiubhais. Hardy as heather, lasting as pine.
Buidheachas an fhogharaidh. Harvest thanksgiving.
Bu choir dhuit bhi buidheach. You ought to be thankful.
Tha mi buidheach airson sin. I am thankful for that.
Chan fhaigh thu sin co dhiu bhitheas tu buidheach no diombach. You won’t get it whether you are pleased or otherwise.
Fo bhuidheachas. Ann am buidheachas??? In abeyance. [NOTE in second hand: new.]
Uair eiridh iad gu neamh, uair theid iad gu doimhne sios. One moment in the heavens and the rest in the depths.
De’n uibhir a th’ann? What quantity is there?
Uibhir ’s a th’ann. As much as there is of it.
Tha mi fhein faotainn na h-uibhir de dhragh. I am likewise getting as much trouble.
Dheanainn sin nam bitheadh an uidheam agam. I would do that if I had the material.
Shoemakers’ tools.
Joiners’ tools.
Tha sin uile air chaochladh. That is all changed.
Thogadh an uir tharta. They are interred. [NOTE in second hand: or Chuireadh.]
Cha n’eil uiread sin agam. I haven’t as much as that.
Ullamh ealamh. Ready, aye ready.
Is ullamh le neach sin a dheanamh. One should be ready to do that.
Cho umhal ri luch fo spoig a’ chait. It’s submissive as a mouse beneath a cat’s paw.
Rinn e umhlachd cheart dha. He gave him a proper salute.
Bheir mi ant-urram [sic] dhuit air na chunnaic mi riamh. I will give you first place over all I ever saw.
A’ leanachd na h-abhaist. Following custom.
Am bi thu cho math agus mo fhreagairt? Will you kindly answer me?
Thoir leat e a dh’fhios nach bi feum agad air. Take it in case of need.
Faoileagan a’ chladaich againn fhein. Our own folk.
Tha m’ inntinn saor o fhein agartas. My mind is free from compunction.
Cuir an aghaidh as fhearr a dh’fhaodas tu air. Put the best face possible on it.
’S ann agad tha’n aghaidh ’ga iarraidh. What a face you have to ask for it.
Dh’aicheadh e chreideamh. He renounced his religion.
’Se an t-aicheadh math an dara pong as fhearr ’san lagh. A stout denial is the second best point in law. [NOTE in second hand: and also without the “dara” restriction.]
Tha mi ag aideachadh mo chionta. I admit my fault.
De’n aidhmheil [sic] a tha e leantuinn? What persuasion does he follow?
Tha aighear a’ bruchdadh na shuil. His eye is filled with joy.
A reir ur n-aidmheil na firium [sic]. According to your profession of the truth.
Tha aighear ri cois na h-oige. Joy is part of youth.
Dean aille de’n eiginn. Make a virtue of necessity.
Co dhiu is deoin leat no’s aindheoin. Whether you be willing or not.
Rinn mi sin gad aindheoin. I did that in spite of you.
Is trom an t-eallach an t-aineolas. Ignorance is a heavy burden.
Aiteamh na gaoithe tuath air an t-sneachda, tuille a chur na cheann. North wind’s way of thawing – to add more snow.
Tha i gle aithneach. She is very considerate.
Amhairc thairis e. Overlook it. [NOTE in second hand: e corrected to air.]
Aithrisibhse [sic] agus aithrisidh sinne. You repeat and so shall we.
Ann am is ann an-am. In and out of season.
Galled, vexed, piqued. [NOTE in second hand: aimhleachadh corrected to aimheallachadh.]
Chaidh e dhachaidh gu h-aindeonach. He went home unwillingly.
Air a bho’n de. Day before yesterday.
Air bho’n raoir. Night before last.
Air chionn dhaibh a bhi deas. By the time they were ready.
Se gaol an airgiod freumh gach uilc. Money is the root of all evil.
Tha mi nad chomain mar a gabh thu ri na thubhairt mi. I am obliged by your attention to my remarks.
Thoir a lathair a cheil iad. Bring them face to face.
Tha e an cas air. He is very desirous of it.
Le an h-iochd. With vigour.
Tha fad math a tighinn san la. The day is getting pretty long.
B’annsa leo sgur. They were glad to desist.
Tha am balla ag aomadh. The wall is bulging.
Lan uabhair is ardain. Full of pride and ignorance.
Gun dad athais. Without any leisure.
Athleasaich do chomhradh is bheusan. Amend your speech and manners.
Is tric nach tig ath-sgeul air droch sgeul. Bad news is seldom refuted.
Bacach air aon choise. Lame of a leg.
A tuft of hair.
Flock of sheep.
A’ bagairt sgainidh. Threatening to burst.
An sobhrach a chinneas badanach. The primrose which grows in tufts.
Tha e fo bhaintighearnas. He is henpecked.
A’ bheatha bhall-bhreac. Chequered career. [NOTE in second hand: non-Gaelic idea.]
Is banntrach e. Is banntrach i. Widower and widow.
Warrant of apprehension.
Bathamaid gach smalan. Let us drown care.
Beadradh gu leoir. Sufficient flirting.
Chuireadh sin na bodaich gu beadradh. It would make even the old flirt.
Tha thu fas beannaichte. You are getting holy (in derision).
Beathaich thusa mise an diugh is beathaichaidh mi am maireach tu. [NOTE in second hand: beathaichaidh mise thusa am maireach.]
Cha n’eil an sugradh a chuir ris. It is no joke to manage him. [NOTE in second hand: Cha n’e an sugradh a cur ris.]
Is taitneach leam t’fhaicinn. I am happy to see you.
Ma se’s taitniche leat. If it is more agreeable to you.
Ma thalaidheas peacaich thu. If sinnners entice you.
Grath fhacal tamailteach. A taunting proverb. [NOTE in second hand: not good.]
Cuir tarruing air. Put an extracting plaster on it.
Cha d’thainig e teach. It did not come to pass. [NOTE in second hand: ?]
Tighinn gu teach. Happening.
Thainig e mu’n teach. It came to pass.
Is iomadh rud a thachaireas an teachd mu’n cuairt na bliadhna. Much may happen before the expiry of a year.
B’e sin teachdaireachd a chuir moran gu truaighe. That news caused many to sorrow.
Na gabhamaid oirnn e. Let us take no notice of him.
Tha tuillidh sa phaidir aig. He knows more than his beads.
Tha e pailt cho ard ruimsa [sic]. He is fully as tall as I.
Chaidh laithean na seachduin iomrall orra. They were confused with the days of the week.
Am fear a theid lideag am mearachd. The man who goes the least bit wrong.
Fear reitich gach teagaimh. The solver of all difficulties.
Thainig a chuis teann-ri teann. The affair assumed a serious aspect.
Cha n’fhaigh thu le tlachd e. You won’t get it with pleasure.
Thig tlath nan speur is blaths fhathast. Balmy air and warmth will come yet.
Neach de’n tuath. One of the common people.
Is trom na tubaistean air na sliobaistean. Frequent the accidents to the clumsy.
Thig tubaist air. Mischief will befall him.
Tha mo mhuineal air a thuchadh. My throat has become hoarse.
Co a thuigeas uile sheachrain fhein. Who understands all his own errors. [NOTE in second hand: Psalm.]
Thuit dhuinn tachairt. We met by chance.
Thuit dhaibh tighinn a steach. They happened to come in.
Bhrùchd cuimhne mar thuil. Memory burst forth like a flood.
Thuit a chridhe. He grew faint hearted.
Fhuair e tuiteam. He got a fall.
Thig tuiteamachd air an darach. Oaks cast their leaves.
Tha iad uile nan tulaichean. They are all in their graves.
Turus math is soirbheasadh leat. Good and prosperous trip to you.
Air a thus is air a thoiseach. First and foremost.
Air tus m’ aimsir. In my early days.
S’e tus a ghliocais eagal Dhe. Fear of God is the beginning of wisdom. [NOTE in second hand: Bib.]
Airson an uabhair. For their pride.
Lan uaibhreachais nad Shaothair. Full of pride in their work.
Thug e air uaigneas e. He took him aside to a private place.
Na dean uaill as an la maireach. Boast not of tomorrow.
Cha n’eil uainn ach an ceartas. We only want justice.
Cuiridh so rudha seachad. This will serve for turn.
Thoir ruith chladaich i. Run the boat aground. [NOTE in second hand: i corrected to dhi.]
Thoir an aon ruith dhaibh. Give them the same treatment.
Is iomadh uair a thug mi ruith air. Many a time I made him run. [NOTE in second hand: had a turn at it.]
Is mor an sabhaladh sin. That is a great retrenchment.
Bha sin sarachail air. That was burdensome on him. [NOTE in second hand: tiresome.]
A’ sasachadh na feola. Satisfying the flesh.
Tha sealladh gobhlach aige. He has a squint. [NOTE in second hand: sealladh fiar.]
Tha mi ’gam sheumadh. I cross myself.
Thoir tuille sgiabaidh do’n’fharadh. Give more slant to the ladder.
Sgiolcaidh am buntata Sgiathanach as an rusg gu barr a chroinn. The Skye potato will jump out of its skin to the mast head. (being so wet)
Gheibh cearc an sgriobain rudeiginn. The scratching hen will get something.
Bheir thu sgrios oirnn. You will annihilate us.
Dh’fhalbh e air slighe na firinn. Said of one who is dead.
Sloinntearachd neo-chriochnaich. Endless genealogies.
Claidhean soc ri soc. Swords point to point.
Se an t-socair a thug orm a dheanamh. Sheer simplicity made me do it. [NOTE in second hand: socair corrected to sochair.]
Bu choir solair-itheannaich sa Ghaidhlig a bhi againn. We should have a Gaelic menu.
Sholaraich i aite dhi fhein. She provided a house for herself.
Co bhitheas a’ solar loin. Who will be purveying.
Braighe na stroine. Bridge of nose. [NOTE in second hand: stroine corrected to sroine.]
Ann an deagh thrath. In good time.
Cha striochdainn do dhuine. I could yield to no one.
B’fheudar dhaibh striochadh [sic]. They were compelled to yield.
Faigh air thoiseach air. Get the start of him.
Is fhad an fhuireachd a rinn thu. You made a long stay.
Thainig e gun fhuireachadh. He came without delay.
Gu fuireach car oidhche. To stay one night. [NOTE in second hand: To stay for one night or so.]
Marcaich cas ghobhlach. Ride astride.
Tha e os cionn mo bheachdsa. It surpasses my comprehension.
Gabh ann an droch sheadh. Take in a bad sense. [NOTE in second hand: sheadh corrected to sheagh.]
Thog thu mi gu docharrach. You took mi up wrongly.
Is moch fhuair e bas. He died untimely. [NOTE in second hand: moch not good – og better.]
Failnichidh rud sam bith le dith cleachda. Anything fails for lack of use. [NOTE in second hand: cleachda corrected to cleachdaidh.]
Tha mi air mo dheagh chleachd ris. I am well accustomed to it. [NOTE in second hand: chleachd corrected to chleachdadh.]
Is mairg a dheanadh subhachas ri dubhachas fir eile. Woe to him who mocks at another’s grief.
Air abaichead ’s gum bi e. However ripe it may be. [NOTE in second hand: ’gum corrected to ’gam.]
Tha e dol an abaichead. It is getting more and more ripe.
Cha deanainn air mhor luach e. I wouldn’t do it at any price.
Mhothaich sinn a ghuth ga threigsinn. We noted his voice going.
Tha airgiod agam mu choinneamh a mhail. Tha [sic] have the money to meet the rent.
Neo sheasmhach mar uisge. Unstable as water. [NOTE in second hand: Reuben – Bible.]
Cha d’fhuair mi a chuireadh neul bharr cait. I didn’t get what would relieve a cat’s faintness. [NOTE in second hand: Cha d’fhuair mi na…]
Muthadh nan neul. Change colour of complexion.
Thanig [sic] neul ’nam cheann. I turned faintish.
Tha e ort a dheanamh. You are obliged to do it.
Foghnaidh so: is leoir so. This will serve.
Chaidh mi ’nam cheo ’s ’nam bhreislich. I was mystified and puzzled.
Chaidh mi bho obair, bho fheum. I was past work and useless.
Chaidh mi thar mo sgeoil (mo shiubhail). I lost the thread of my story.
Chaidh mo thoirt as mo ghabhail. I have been disappointed in my original intention.
Cha deach sin gu math dhaibh. That upset them.
Rabhairt an diugh is conntraigh am maireach. Up today and down tomorrow. [NOTE in second hand: Spring tide to-day, neap-tide to-morrow.]
Bu ro chaomh leam tighinn. I should like very much to come.
Bheil romhad thu fhein a mhilleadh. Do you intend to ruin yourself. [NOTE in second hand: ruin or damage.]
A steady light.
Steady motion.
Turnstile.
Stile.
Ann am bheag bhriathan. To sum up all.
Na’s luaithe na shaoileas tu. Sooner than you think.
La geal samhraidh. A fine summer’s day.
Abair gur ann mar so a thu chuis. Suppose the case to be thus.
Droch agus deagh charamh. Good and bad usage.
Cha mholadh do mholadh. Your praise is dispraise. [NOTE in second hand: Your praise is worthless.]
Tha iad uile mi tharbhach. They are all unprofitable.
Tha e mu thuath. He has gone North.
Chaidh iad gu bron is briseadh cridhe. They gave way to grief and sorrow.
Chaidh mi rithist gu mo smuaintean. I reconsidered matters.
Roinn mhic is athar. Share and share alike.
Abair romhad. Say on.
Bithidh mise romhad fhathast. I shall be upsides with you yet. [NOTE in second hand: I shall be ahead of you yet.]
Tha an t-iasg ’na ruadhan. The fish is overcooked.
Burn glan gun ruadhan. Water without sediment.
Tha so ann thuille na corach (an deigh laimhe). That remains over and above.
Cha tug mi meas freagairt air. I did not think him worthy of a reply. [NOTE in second hand: Cha d’thug…]
Chronaich esan e gu geur. Dheagh throid e ris. He reprimanded him sharply.
Choisinn e droch chliu (iomradh). He gained a bad reputation.
Air m’ iarrtas. At my request.
Cha toill iarrtas achmhasan. A request does not deserve blame.
Shaor e iad a sgrios. He saved them from destruction. [NOTE in second hand: …bho sgrios.]
Tha cuid dhubhailcean ann aig am bheil aogas subhailc. Some vices have the appearance of virtues.

Cuir gu dearbhadh. Put to the proof.

Cuir cuil ri (treig) do chompanaich. Renounce your companions.

Sasuich do mhiann. Satisfy your ambition.

An da shreath. In two ranks.

Tha mi dol a ghabhail ceum spaidearaiche. I am going for an airing.

Thug e teann sparradh dhaibh. He gave them a strict injunction.

An leith as mo. The majority.
A bye election.
A general election.

A’ cur nan car dheth. Dreadfully busy.

Leth-char ur. Somewhat new.

Leaven.
Putty.
Politics.
Liberals.
Conservatives.
Unionists.
Socialists.
Communist.
Reactionary.
Policy of party.
Foreign policy.
Nationalists.
Imperial politics.
Popularity.
Tha e tuille is uasal uime. He is too fastidious about it.

A minor.
